event.title: opened the reservation for white settlement in November 1895

data.event: Winchester is within the Nez Perce Indian Reservation, and similar to the opening of lands in Oklahoma, the U.S. government opened the reservation for white settlement in November 1895.

event.title: had been signed less than two weeks earlier

data.event: The proclamation had been signed less than two weeks earlier by President Cleveland.
The city was named in 1900 during a meeting to establish a school district.
The sawmill closed in May 1965 after the mature timber in the area had been cut.

event.title: was operated by Boise Cascade for its final five years

data.event: The mill was operated by Boise Cascade for its final five years; its closure followed a fire which destroyed much of downtown Winchester in November 1964.

event.title: destroyed much of downtown Winchester in November 1964

data.event: The mill was operated by Boise Cascade for its final five years; its closure followed a fire which destroyed much of downtown Winchester in November 1964.
A half mile (1 km) outside of town is Winchester Lake State Park, planned in 1966 and established in 1969.
A half mile (1 km) outside of town is Winchester Lake State Park, planned in 1966 and established in 1969.
Originally it was a mill pond, created in 1910 by damming Lapwai Creek.

event.title: were addressed with the installation of aeration units in 2002

data.event: Water quality issues at the lake were addressed with the installation of aeration units in 2002.
